content.html:
Today I learned 1 600 metres is very nearly 1 mile.

4 laps.
content.value: Today I learned 1 600 metres is very nearly 1 mile. 4 laps.

content.html:
Today I learned the largest unit of time is the Hubble Time, 13.8 billion years. Take the rate of expansion of the observable universe and run it backwards until the whole coalesces to a point. That's 1 Hubble Time, and also the time since the Big Bang with the big rep.

I am searching for: "longest measure of time in any culture," but I want to include only those units which repeat.

There's the millenium, 1 000 years, everyone knows that one. I am reminded of the Y2K earworm by Robbie Williams, "Millenium.". There is also the eon, a measure of geological time. It's several millions of years but has no fixed amount. Eons are not all of the same duration. There's an alternate spelling, aeon, which is either the same as eon, or an unfixed and indefinite amount. In the source Greek, it is literally 100 years.

In the sanskrit we have, महाकल्प (mahakalpa), which derives from the same archaic source word as our eon but is culturally understood to mean 1.33424 billion years (1 334 240 000), the life cycle of the world.

Oh, how could I forget Unix time? The 32-bit signed unix time will roll-over and start it's second cycle sometime in 2038. The 64-bit unsigned unix time is a duration so expansive, 584 billion years, it makes the Hubble Time look small.

An exercise for the reader: since the definition of the Hubble Time depends on the age current state of the observable universe, it has a duration which steadily increases. Will the Hubble Time have greater duration than the 64-bit unsigned unix time, someday?
content.value:
Today I learned the largest unit of time is the Hubble Time, 13.8 billion years. Take the rate of expansion of the observable universe and run it backwards until the whole coalesces to a point. That's 1 Hubble Time, and also the time since the Big Bang with the big rep.
I am searching for: "longest measure of time in any culture," but I want to include only those units which repeat.
There's the millenium, 1 000 years, everyone knows that one. I am reminded of the Y2K earworm by Robbie Williams, "Millenium.". There is also the eon, a measure of geological time. It's several millions of years but has no fixed amount. Eons are not all of the same duration. There's an alternate spelling, aeon, which is either the same as eon, or an unfixed and indefinite amount. In the source Greek, it is literally 100 years.
In the sanskrit we have, महाकल्प (mahakalpa), which derives from the same archaic source word as our eon but is culturally understood to mean 1.33424 billion years (1 334 240 000), the life cycle of the world.

Oh, how could I forget Unix time? The 32-bit signed unix time will roll-over and start it's second cycle sometime in 2038. The 64-bit unsigned unix time is a duration so expansive, 584 billion years, it makes the Hubble Time look small.
An exercise for the reader: since the definition of the Hubble Time depends on the age current state of the observable universe, it has a duration which steadily increases. Will the Hubble Time have greater duration than the 64-bit unsigned unix time, someday?

content.html:
Testing out syntax highlighting for shell sessions w/ Prism.

$ du -Bh
4.0K    .
$ ls -la
total 8
drwxrwxr-x  2 priv priv 4096 Nov 26 15:10 .
drwxr-xr-x 13 priv priv 4096 Nov 26 15:09 ..
-rw-rw-r--  1 priv priv    0 Nov 26 15:10 test
content.value:
Testing out syntax highlighting for shell sessions w/ Prism.
$ du -Bh
4.0K    .
$ ls -la
total 8
drwxrwxr-x  2 priv priv 4096 Nov 26 15:10 .
drwxr-xr-x 13 priv priv 4096 Nov 26 15:09 ..
-rw-rw-r--  1 priv priv    0 Nov 26 15:10 test

content.html: Each workday I lift off yesterday's business and write the date and day-of-employment number at the top-left of a fresh sheet of paper. It comes in handy for reference over the course of days or weeks depending on what goes on. I have had this habit for about five years now.
